content: be to father some new cobalt milkweed beetles and drops off to seek out his next mate but he s not just annoying her- some research suggests that riding around on her back can protect her from predation if you happen to be around a patch of milkweed during their mating period around 6 weeks in early summer bend down and look close to the stalk of the plant- it s highly likely you ll see some beetles making the next generation for more resources on beetles of which there are around 5 000 species and other insects of which there are…way more in oregon and just in general i highly recommend the following resources 1 inaturalist inaturalist org a inaturalist is a community science platform dedicated to documenting biodiversity you can take a photo upload it with your location and have that photograph identified by experts even better that photo goes on to forever document the presence of a species that can help researchers like me document their ranges and abundances over time especially in urban areas like portland documenting biodiversity when and where you see it is crucial in helping to preserve our wildlife 2 oregon department of agriculture phenomenal resources online for identifying different insects 3 wild in the city a guide to portland s natural areas by michael c houck & m j cody this book is a primer for the urban ecology of your ecoregion 2 yardage
